Q0.reasoning: Patient info states whole-genome sequencing (WGS) is being considered to identify a genetic cholestatic/metabolic etiology.

Q1.reasoning: Policy age criterion: WES/WGS indications apply to individuals <18 years. Patient is one week old (<18), so age criterion is met (Policy Section II: criteria for individuals less than 18 years).

Q2.reasoning: Policy (II.1.a) requires evaluation by an ABMGG board-certified medical geneticist or an ABGC board-certified genetic counselor and counseling; the ordering provider is a neonatologist and no geneticist/genetic counselor involvement is documented.

Q3.reasoning: Policy allows WGS only after WES fails to identify a causative mutation and other criteria are met (II.4). The patient has not had WES yet, so does not meet the policy's specified medical indication for WGS.

Q4.reasoning: Policy requires WES (and negative/non-diagnostic WES) before WGS is covered (II.4 and II.5); patient has nondiagnostic karyotype but no WES performed, so required prior testing has not been completed.

Q5.reasoning: Patient has a relevant family history: a sibling with unexplained developmental regression. Policy references family/pedigree context (trio testing and prior affected sibling scenarios) as relevant to sequencing indications (Sections II and V).

Q6.reasoning: Policy (II.1.a and prenatal guidance) requires pre-test counseling by an ABMGG geneticist or ABGC genetic counselor; no pre-test genetic counseling is documented for this patient.

Q7.reasoning: The provided policy document does not list or map CPT billing codes to WES/WGS, so a specific CPT code cannot be determined from the policy text.

Q8.reasoning: Per policy, WGS meets coverage only when WES has been performed and failed to identify a causative mutation and when geneticist/genetic counselor evaluation and counseling are documented (II.4 and II.1.a). The patient has not had WES and lacks documented pre-test genetic counseling by an ABMGG/ABGC provider; therefore WGS is not covered.
